Zimbabwe commemorates International Childhood Cancer Day
news.content:
Rumbidzayi Zinyuke

Senior Health Reporter

Zimbabwe today joined the world to commemorate the International Childhood Cancer Day (ICCD), a global initiative dedicated to raising awareness about childhood cancers and providing support for affected children, adolescents and their families.

The day, which is observed on February 15 annually, was celebrated early at the Rainbow Childrens Village, bringing together various stakeholders and survivors.

It was held under the theme Inspiring change: finding solutions to the challenges identified in 2024.

Each year, an estimated 400 000 children and adolescents aged 0-19 years develop cancer globally.

The most common types of childhood cancers include leukemia, brain cancers, lymphomas, and solid tumours.

In low and middle-income countries, less than 30 percent of children with cancer survive while more than 80 percent of their counterparts in high-income countries are cured.

news.title: Woman defrauds niece of US$350 000
news.content:
Yeukai Karengezeka

Court Correspondent

A 51-year-old Harare woman appeared in court yesterday facing charges of defrauding her niece of US$350 000 through a fraudulent investment scheme that promised high returns.

Doreen Mandivenga, a Sentosa resident, was arrested on February 12.

She was remanded in custody pending her bail ruling on February 17.

According to State prosecutor Mr Anesu Chirenje, Mandivenga allegedly lured her niece, Peacemaker Nyevero Makuve, a 39-year-old construction business director, into the scheme by claiming that it was a lucrative, risk-free investment opportunity offering a minimum 4 percent return.

The alleged scam ran from May 2023 to September 2024, during which Makuve invested a total of US$350 000.

Mandivenga reportedly issued promissory notes as proof of receipt and even paid Makuve US$110 000 in interest to maintain the illusion of legitimacy.

However, when Makuve sought further returns or attempted to withdraw her principal investment, Mandivenga became evasive.

When repeated attempts to recover her funds failed, Makuve reported the matter to the police, leading to Mandivengas arrest.

The court heard that Mandivenga worked with an accomplice, Jesman Chonzi, who has not yet been apprehended.

Authorities have confirmed that no funds have been recovered to date.

news.title: DRC musician killed during video shoot
news.content:
A popular musician in the Democratic Republic of Congo has been killed while filming a music video in the conflict-hit eastern town of Goma.

The body of Delphin Katembo Vinywasiki, better known as Delcat Idengo, was found in a street on Thursday with his head partially covered with blood. Unconfirmed reports say the artist was shot. BBC

news.title: PSL gate charges, kick-off announced
news.content:
Online Reporter

The Premier Soccer League has confirmed the details for the 2025 Castle Challenge Cup set for February 22.

The encounter will act as a season opener for the 2025 campaign and will be played between Castle Lager Premier Soccer League champions Simba Bhora and Chibuku Super Cup winners Dynamos.

The match will take place at Rufaro Stadium.

Kick-off time has been set at 2:30 pm.

The minimum entry price is $3 for the rest of the ground. Grand stands ticket cost $5, while the VIP tickets go for $10.

The VVIP stand is strictly by invitation.

news.title: Decomposing body found in mine shaft
news.content:
Midlands Bureau

A Zeplin Mine employee in Mvuma on Tuesday discovered a decomposing male body as he was checking water levels in a 30-metre mineshaft.

Midlands Provincial police spokesperson, Inspector Emmanuel Mahoko confirmed the incident.

The incident occurred on Tuesday at around 2pm.

Inspector Mahoko said Maxwell Mutakura was pumping water from the shaft when he discovered the body, which was partly submerged.

He said the matter was reported to the police and the body was taken to Mvuma Hospital for a post-mortem.

We are appealing to members of the public who might be missing a relative to come forward and help identify this body, he said.

There had not been any mining operations at the shaft since the beginning of the rainy season.

news.title: African Peer Review Forum convenes to address governance issues
news.content:
Online Reporter

The African Peer Review Forum (APR Forum) of Heads of State and Government is currently underway, bringing together leaders from across the continent to assess governance challenges and progress within African Union (AU) Member States that have voluntarily joined the African Peer Review Mechanism (APRM).

The APR Forum serves as a vital platform where participating Heads of State and Government engage in a peer review process to evaluate Country Review and Targeted Review reports, as well as National Plans of Action.

Additionally, the Africa Governance Report will be presented, offering insights into governance trends and challenges across the continent.

The ongoing session will focus on strategies for enhancing democratic governance, economic management, and social development, ensuring that policies align with the continents broader vision for inclusive growth and stability.

As discussions continue, the outcomes of the APR Forum are expected to shape policy recommendations to strengthen governance frameworks and promote resilience within African States.

The meeting underscores Africas commitment to self-assessment and reform, reinforcing the role of peer learning in driving positive change.

news.title: Leaders to pledge support for AU Peace Fund
news.content:
Online Reporter

In a landmark effort to secure sustainable financing for peace across Africa, leaders, financial institutions and private sector stakeholders will convene to pledge support for the African Union (AU) Peace Fund and explore innovative funding models for African-led peace initiatives.

The high-level meeting, set to take place tomorrow ( Saturday), aims to address the pressing need for sustainable peace financing, ensuring that Africa has the resources to prevent and resolve conflicts independently.

The AU Peace Fund, established to support peacekeeping missions and conflict resolution efforts, remains underfunded despite its critical role in maintaining security on the continent.

The upcoming pledging conference will seek commitments from governments, multilateral organisations, and private entities to strengthen the funds financial base.

In addition to securing pledges, participants will explore innovative funding mechanisms such as public-private partnerships, impact investment strategies, and leveraging technology for transparent resource mobilisation.

With conflicts and security challenges persisting in various parts of Africa, leaders recognise the urgent need to establish a robust, self-reliant financing framework to reduce dependence on external donors.

The outcomes of the meeting are expected to shape the future of peace financing on the continent, reinforcing Africas commitment to home-grown solutions for long-term stability and growth.

news.title: Pastor neglects children, ordered to pay US$100 in child support
news.content:
Anotida Chonzi

Court Correspondent

A Harare pastor, Simbarashe Mparira, has been ordered to pay US$100 per month as maintenance for his two children.

His former partner, Talent Chigwanha, appeared before the Harare Civil Court and said Mparira has not been providing for his children.

She said she is struggling to provide for the children on her own.

I have been providing for my two children all this while, but as they grow up their needs are becoming more expensive, she said.

I had no choice but to seek legal help due to Mpariras prolonged absence and neglect.

She said she only receives financial support from Mpariras church.

However, Mparira opposed the application and told the court that he is unemployed.

I am unemployed and my financial situation is bad. The church is still in its infancy and does not have enough resources, he said.

Mparira offered to pay US$20 every month for both children but the magistrate ordered him to pay US$100.

news.title: Harare gears up for climate action
news.content:
Diana Nherera

Suburban Reporter

The City of Harare and the Combined Harare Residents Association held an environment and climate policy workshop yesterday to address issues to do with water conservation, wetlands management, road infrastructure management and flash flooding.

The local authoritys head of the environmental management unit, Mr Lisben Chipfunde said the city does not have an environment and climate policy.

There are so many problems that are environment and climate change-related but we didnt have a policy to guide us on how to manage them, he said.

From 2019, the city set up an environment management unit responsible for ensuring proper coordination and management of climate and environmental management.

So when they put this unit, they then realised there was no policy direction. Using the bottom-up approach, we have consulted residents to find out what they would want in the policy to address the challenges they are facing.

He said the feedback they got was put into various thematic areas.

We are also in consultation with the Government, residents associations, other local authorities, industry and institutions of higher learning, he said.

We want to hear what they want the policy to address, said Mr Chipfunde.

Acting Harare Mayor, Councillor Womberaiishe Nhende said the environment and climate policy will take Harares growth dynamics into account.

Speaking at the workshop, Councillor Nhende said, If you look at Harare today, you will see that there is rapid growth of the city and the population. Our environment policy must speak to these dynamics, he said.

He appealed for technical and financial resources in drafting the policy.

The onus lies on everyone in here, it must then cascade to all the other provinces for the betterment of the nation.
